title: Using warwickplots with ggplot2
text: Use scale_colour_palette_d() scale_fill_palette_d() discrete scales.
code: p +   scale_colour_palette_d(warwick_palettes$primary) p +   scale_colour_palette_d(warwick_palettes$primary[c(1, 3, 5)]) mpg_p <- mpg |>    filter(class != "2seater") |>    ggplot(aes(y = fl, fill = class)) +     geom_bar() +     scale_fill_palette_d(warwick_palettes$primary) +     theme_warwick()  mpg_p

title: Using warwickplots with ggplot2
text: Use scale_colour_palette_c() scale_fill_palette_c() continuous scales scale_colour_palette_b() scale_fill_palette_b() binned scales.
code: ggplot(diamonds[sample(nrow(diamonds), 1000), ], aes(carat, price)) +   geom_point(aes(colour = clarity)) +   scale_colour_palette_d(warwick_palettes$aubergine) eruptions <- ggplot(faithfuld, aes(waiting, eruptions, fill = density)) +   geom_tile()  eruptions + scale_fill_palette_c(warwick_palettes$ruby) eruptions + scale_fill_palette_b(warwick_palettes$teal)

title: Using warwickplots with ggplot2
text: demonstrate divergent palettes, ’ll first generate synthetic data plot map: can now add divergent colour palette:  default, fill scale’s mid-point mean groups. want zero, can use rescaler argument ggplot2::continuous_scale(), accepts function used scale input values range [0, 1], scale fill values mid-point zero. scaling mid-point use scales::rescale_mid().  See using palettes ggplot2 vignette palettes package details.
code: library(maps) # Get US state boundaries us_states <- map_data("state")  # Generate synthetic data set.seed(123) states <- unique(us_states$region) n <- length(states) data <- data.frame(   region = states,   value = rnorm(n, mean = .5) )  # Merge the synthetic data with the map data us_states <- us_states |>    left_join(data, by = "region")  # Create the plot (without colour) map_p <- ggplot(us_states, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill = value)) +   geom_polygon(color = "white") +   labs(title = "Divergent Data by US State") +   theme_warwick() map_p +    scale_fill_palette_c(warwick_palettes$aubergine_ruby) map_p +   scale_fill_palette_c(warwick_palettes$aubergine_ruby,                        rescaler = ~ scales::rescale_mid(.x, mid = 0))

title: Using warwickplots with ggplot2
text: Let’s return earlier examples see get theme_warwick(). theme_warwick() makes use ggtext::element_textbox_simple() plot title subtitle. allows us make use markdown CSS styles text, also enables text-wrapping:  can now use theme() make adjustments appearance plot. Now colour different species subtitle, longer need legend. Let’s also alter text. Note title set theme_warwick() ggtext::element_textbox_simple(), need use subsequent call theme, whereas change appearance text, e.g. caption, just need standard ggplot2::element_text():  Note title subtitle now less space . , theme_warwick() spacing defined definition plot.title now overwritten, need put back. can inspect source code calling theme_warwick console (without parentheses), View(theme_warwick). can see whole definition plot.title put definition margin back (text colour can stay ):
code: new_p <- p + labs(subtitle = "Flipper length and body mass for **Adelie**, **Chinstrap** and **Gentoo** Penguins. This is based on data made available in the **palmerpenguins** R package.") + scale_color_palette_d(warwick_palettes$primary) new_p new_p + theme(legend.position = "none", plot.title = ggtext::element_textbox_simple(size = rel(1.6)), plot.caption = element_text(colour = "#CB333B")) new_p + theme(legend.position = "none", plot.title = element_textbox_simple(size = rel(1.6), margin = margin(12, 0, 6, 0)), plot.caption = element_text(colour = "#CB333B"))

what: Typography and setting up custom fonts
title: Using warwickplots with ggplot2
text: University Warwick’s typography brand guidance use font Lato online text font Avenir Next print material. theme_warwick() use argument, can one "online" "print" (defaults "online"), ensure appropriate font use, system set , .e. fonts installed packages render plot. details ensure system properly set , see get started warwickplots vignette.

title: Getting started with warwickplots
text: package offers six colour palettes: one discrete, two divergent three sequential:  warwick_palettes essentially list, individual palettes can accessed name:1 palette essentially vector, can subsetted usual way create new palettes: palettes package provides palettes::pal_ramp() function interpolating colours. example, consider warwick_palettes$aubergine palette:  generate new palette five colour values darkest mid-point full palette, reverse (visualise ), can following:  methods working palettes, see palettes vignette palettes package.
code: library(warwickplots) plot(warwick_palettes) warwick_palettes$primary #> <palettes_colour[6]> #> • #3C1053 #> • #6DCDB8 #> • #CB333B #> • #F1BE48 #> • #E87722 #> • #00A9CE warwick_palettes$primary[c(1, 3, 5)] #> <palettes_colour[3]> #> • #3C1053 #> • #CB333B #> • #E87722 plot(warwick_palettes$aubergine) ends <- warwick_palettes$aubergine[c(1, 4)] # get new end-points pal_ramp(ends, n = 5, direction = -1) |> plot()

title: Getting started with warwickplots
text: palettes package provides colour fill scales using palettes ggplot2. : scale_colour_palette_d() scale_colour_palette_c() scale_colour_palette_c() scale_fill_palette_d() scale_fill_palette_c() scale_fill_palette_c() _d variants discrete scales, _c variants continuous scales _b variants binned scales. See using warwickplots ggplot2 vignettes information examples also using palettes ggplot2 vignette palettes package. palettes package also vignettes demonstrating use palettes gt package biscale package.

what: Typography and setting up custom fonts
title: Getting started with warwickplots
text: University Warwick’s typography brand guidance use font Lato online text font Avenir Next print material. theme_warwick() use argument, can one "online" "print" (defaults "online"), ensure appropriate font use, system set , .e. fonts installed packages render plot. section contains guidance making sure system suitably set-.

previous_headings: Typography and setting up custom fonts
title: Getting started with warwickplots
text: need ragg, systemfonts, textshaping packages installed. Installing ragg install two: need ensure whenever output plot, using AGG graphics device. RStudio >= 1.4, go Tools -> Global Options -> General -> Graphics set Backend AGG. Quarto, set following YAML:2 RMarkdown, use knitr::opts_chunk$set(dev = "ragg_png") top script.

previous_headings: Typography and setting up custom fonts
title: Getting started with warwickplots
text: use either fonts, first need check installed system: paths tibble show Lato Avenir Next, installed system. show another font, .e. system default, . example, environment vignette rendered, access Lato, Avenir Next. tried set font family plot Avenir Next, display default DejaVuSans instead. Lato installed, can install , either directly Google Fonts using sysfonts package: excellent, detailed guidance setting working custom fonts R, see getting fonts work R post Cara Thompson setting debugging custom fonts post June Choe.
code: systemfonts::match_fonts(c("Lato", "Avenir Next")) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   path                                            index features   #>   <chr>                                           <int> <list>     #> 1 /usr/share/fonts/truetype/lato/Lato-Regular.ttf     0 <font_ftr> #> 2 /usr/share/fonts/truetype/dejavu/DejaVuSans.ttf     0 <font_ftr> sysfonts::font_add_google("Lato")

what: Palettes and Themes Consistent with The University of Warwick's Brand
title: Palettes and Themes Consistent with The University of Warwick's Brand
text: R package colour palettes ggplot2 theme consistent University Warwick’s branding, especially colours typography. palettes built using palettes package. ggplot2 theme heavily inspired work Cara Thompson, particularly talk applying unifying aesthetic plots.

title: Palettes and Themes Consistent with The University of Warwick's Brand
text: can install development version warwickplots GitHub :

title: Palettes and Themes Consistent with The University of Warwick's Brand
text: package offers six colour palettes: one discrete, two divergent three sequential:  details using palettes, please see warwickplots vignette documentation palettes package.
code: library(warwickplots) #> Loading required package: palettes plot(warwick_palettes)

title: Palettes and Themes Consistent with The University of Warwick's Brand
text: plot uses warwick_palettes::primary palette theme_warwick().  theme_warwick() extension ggplot2::theme_minimal(), offering following addition: Text hierarchy, different sizes colours Spacing, giving text room breathe Uses ggtext::element_textbox_simple() plot title subtitle, enable use markdown CSS styling, text-wrapping title/subtitle long Places legend plot Uses Lato Avenir Next font (online print use respectively), system set Note theme_warwick() defaults can overridden subsequent call theme(). details, including ensure system set use custom fonts, see get started warwickplots vignette. examples, including override theme_warwick(), see using warwickplots ggplot2 vignette.
code: library(ggplot2) library(palmerpenguins) ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g, group = species)) + geom_point(aes(colour = species, shape = species), alpha = 0.8, size = 2) + scale_color_palette_d(warwick_palettes$primary) + labs(title = "Penguin Size, Palmer Station LTER", subtitle = "Flipper length and body mass for **Adelie**, **Chinstrap** and **Gentoo** Penguins. This is based on data made available in the **palmerpenguins** R package.", caption = "Visualization: Ella Kaye, Data: Gorman, Williams & Fraser (2014) DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.009008", x = "flipper length (mm)", y = "body mass (g)") + theme_warwick() + theme(legend.position = 'none')

what: ggplot2 theme consistent with Warwick Brand — theme_warwick
title: ggplot2 theme consistent with Warwick Brand — theme_warwick
text: theme_warwick() extension ggplot2::theme_minimal(). See Details.

title: ggplot2 theme consistent with Warwick Brand — theme_warwick
ggplot2 theme consistent with Warwick Brand — theme_warwick
text: base_size numeric, base size font use character, one "online" "print" (defaults "online"), determines font used

title: ggplot2 theme consistent with Warwick Brand — theme_warwick
text: theme_warwick() extension ggplot2::theme_minimal(), offering following addition: Spacing, giving text room breathe Uses ggtext::element_textbox_simple() plot title subtitle, enable use markdown CSS styling, text-wrapping title/subtitle long Places legend plot Uses Lato Avenir Next font (online print use respectively), system set Note theme_warwick() defaults can overridden subsequent call theme(). details, including ensure system set use custom fonts, see warwickplots vignette. examples, see using warwickplots ggplot2 vignette.

title: ggplot2 theme consistent with Warwick Brand — theme_warwick
code: if (FALSE) { ggplot2::ggplot(mtcars, ggplot2::aes(mpg, wt)) +    ggplot2::geom_point() +    ggplot2::labs(title = "A demo plot") +    theme_warwick() }

title: University of Warwick brand palettes — warwick_palettes
text: https://github.com/Warwick-Stats-Resources/warwickplots

title: University of Warwick brand palettes — warwick_palettes
text: information University Warwick's brand colours, see https://warwick.ac.uk//brand/brand-guidelines/colours/. primary palette combination primary brand colour (aubergine) five bright accent colours. colours brand team uses graphs PowerPoint template. three sequential palettes run bright colour 30% tint. Since primary Warwick brand aubergine much darker bright accent colours, strong starting point aubergine side divergent palettes. achieve better balance, aubergine_ruby starts 80% tint primary aubergine, aubergine_teal starts 70% tint.

title: University of Warwick brand palettes — warwick_palettes
text: Ella Kaye

title: University of Warwick brand palettes — warwick_palettes
code: # Get all palettes by name names(warwick_palettes) #> [1] "primary"        "aubergine"      "teal"           "ruby"           #> [5] "aubergine_ruby" "aubergine_teal"  # Plot a specific palette plot(warwick_palettes$primary)   # Subset a palette warwick_palettes$primary[c(1, 3, 5)] #> <palettes_colour[3]> #> • #3C1053 #> • #CB333B #> • #E87722  #' # Plot all palettes if (FALSE) { plot(warwick_palettes) }

what: warwickplots: Palettes and Themes Consistent with The University of Warwick's Brand — warwickplots-package
title: warwickplots: Palettes and Themes Consistent with The University of Warwick's Brand — warwickplots-package
text: Colour palettes 'ggplot2' theme consistent University Warwick' branding. Built using 'palettes' package, provides methods printing, formatting, casting coercion, extraction updating components, plotting, colour mixing arithmetic, colour interpolation.

title: warwickplots: Palettes and Themes Consistent with The University of Warwick's Brand — warwickplots-package
text: Maintainer: Ella Kaye ella.m.kaye@warwick.ac.uk (ORCID)
